docs.lead_paragraph: Government health and safety regulators rarely impose new costs on businesses. They simply re-allocate who pays the costs.

headline.main: Safety Regulators Don’t Add Costs. They Decide Who Pays Them.
headline.print_headline: Safety Regulators Don’t Add Costs. They Decide Who Pays Them.

docs.snippet: Government health and safety regulators rarely impose new costs on businesses. They simply re-allocate who pays the costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: The truth about Medicare: what it pays for is not what most recipients need or want.
docs.abstract: Author and former reporter Jane Gross Op-Ed article argues mismatch between what is covered by Medicare and what is actually useful is the central flaw of the program; asserts that the elderly benefit and need chronic care more than acute care, and yet no one is addressing the issue save the insular community of long-term care providers.
docs.snippet: The truth about Medicare: what it pays for is not what most recipients need or want.

docs.lead_paragraph: A law restricting public employees’ bargaining rights, stricter than Wisconsin’s version, faces a repeal vote.

headline.seo: In Ohio, a Battle Over Public Employees’ Bargaining Rights
headline.main: Ohio Wages Fierce Fight on Collective Bargaining
headline.print_headline: Limits on Collective Bargaining Face Fierce Repeal Fight in Ohio

docs.abstract: Ohio law restricting public employees' collective bargaining rights, even stricter than Wisconsin’s better-known measure, faces fierce repeal battle.
docs.snippet: A law restricting public employees’ bargaining rights, stricter than Wisconsin’s version, faces a repeal vote.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States and its allies need to find better ways to persuade China to change policies that are both battering the global economy and damaging its own future.
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts United States and its allies need to find better ways to persuade China to change policies that are both battering the global economy and damaging its own development; argues that a more expensive renminbi is part of the answer for China and its trading partners.
docs.snippet: The United States and its allies need to find better ways to persuade China to change policies that are both battering the global economy and damaging its own future.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nationally, black babies are twice as likely as white infants to die before age 1.

headline.seo: Efforts to Combat High Infant Mortality Rate Among Blacks
headline.main: Tackling Infant Mortality Rates Among Blacks
headline.print_headline: Tackling High Infant Mortality Rates Among Blacks

docs.abstract: Several health programs nationwide offer care and attention to mothers to help reduce rate of infant mortality for black babies, who are statistically more than twice as likely to die than white babies before the age of one year; however, health officials implementing programs, like Healthy Start in Pittsburgh, PA, say apathy and state and federal budget cuts are hampering their progress.
docs.snippet: Nationally, black babies are twice as likely as white infants to die before age 1.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Texas, Mike Toomey is respected and feared for his keen intellect, tough political tactics and relationship with Rick Perry.

headline.seo: Mike Toomey, Texas Lobbyist, Is Power Behind Perry
headline.main: For Perry, Lobbyist Is a Take-No-Prisoners Ally
headline.print_headline: For Perry, Lobbyist Is a Take-No-Prisoners Ally

docs.abstract: Mike Toomey is a lobbyist, a former legislator and a onetime chief of staff to Texas Gov Rick Perry who has tapped a sprawling network of donors, business allies and friendly or indebted lawmakers to help Perry accomplish ambitious political and legislative goals; should Perry win the Republican nomination for presidency and, later on, the presidency, it will be in no small measure because of the efforts of Toomey.
docs.snippet: In Texas, Mike Toomey is respected and feared for his keen intellect, tough political tactics and relationship with Rick Perry.

byline.contributor: Sam Bacarisse contributed reporting. Jay Root, Ross Ramsey and Mr. Bacarisse write for The Texas Tribune, which produces a twice-weekly local section in the Texas editions of The New York Times.
byline.original: By JAY ROOT, ROSS RAMSEY and JIM RUTENBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration says a long-term care program, known as Class, would be too costly.

headline.seo: Long-Term Care Program Cut From Health Law
headline.main: Health Law to Be Revised by Ending a Program
headline.print_headline: Health Law To Be Revised By Ending A Program

docs.abstract: Obama administration cuts long-term insurance program created as part of health care law to help people with chronic and severe disabilities, saying that the premiums would be too costly and program would not work; decision is another setback for health insurance legislation, which is under attack in court, in Congress and in many state legislatures.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration says a long-term care program, known as Class, would be too costly.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Bank of America's new monthly debit card fee has been roundly criticized in recent weeks. But a new change in corporate policy change is likely to receive a much warmer reception. Starting next year, the nation's largest bank will begin reimbursing its employees with same-sex partners for the extra taxes they pay for health insurance - something that their married heterosexual co-workers don't have to worry about because the federal government recognizes them as an economic unit.
docs.abstract: Bucks blog; Bank of America, beginning in 2012, will reimburse employees with same-sex partners, who are not married or whose marriage is not legally recognized, for the extra taxes that they have to pay for health insurance. (M)
docs.snippet: Bank of America's new monthly debit card fee has been roundly criticized in recent weeks. But a new change in corporate policy change is likely to receive a much warmer reception.     Starting next year, the nation's largest bank will begin...
